results.title: Smoking and you
results.creator_credit: Derrick Knight and Partners, Great Britain. Ministry of Health and Derrick Knight
results.brief_description: The risks of cigarette smoking, factually presented with the object of discouraging young smokers. Effects of smoking on the throat and lungs are explained in diagrams and illustrated by the cases of two heavy smokers; research with a smoking machine shows the amount of chemicals inhaled; and animated sequence shows the rise in smoking and the number of deaths from lung cancer since 1910.

results.title: Smoking and kids
results.creator_credit: Morley Skolnek, Sandler Institutional Films and Bryon Meyers
results.brief_description: Many children are caught up in peer pressures that induce them to drink, eat, inhale or inject substances that may harm them. This film provides an opportunity to bring some of the children’s problems into the open, and to think about alleviating them.

results.title: Smoking and health: a report to youth
results.creator_credit: Design Center, Bailey Film Productions and Jeff Whatley
results.brief_description: If you smoke, chances are that you will get lung cancer. Is smoking worth the chance? This is the only question asked in the film and the answer must come from the viewer after they have seen how the human body is affected by smoking. The evidence against smoking is over-whelming but the decision rests with the individual.

results.title: Smokey Joe's revenge
results.brief_description: When nasty old Mr. Williams replaces his ols steam engine with a new model, three local children repair and restore the old engine (Smokey Joe). They win first prize at the steam engine fair, but Mr. Williams takes the trophy, claiming Smokey Joe is his engine. But Smokey Joe has plans of his own.

results.title: Smoke signal
results.brief_description: Stressing the importance of forest products to Tasmania, this film deals with the causes of forest firest and methods of control. Shows how each township has its own volunteer Rural Fire Organisation, supplemented by the fire-fighting resources of the Forestry Department - cooperation to keep Tasmania green. The main causes of fire are smoldering cigarette butts, camp fires left unattended, and the deliberate burning of dry grass.

results.title: Smile of Buddha
results.creator_credit: Office de Radiodiffusion Television Francais, UNICEF and Yves Gautier
results.brief_description: The sparrows of Saigon of the opening song refer to the thousands of homeless and injured children of this city, who are both victims of the war or whose already miserable condition the war has worsened. Orphanages and hospitals provide some of these children with food and care. Various nurses and organisers in these places, speak about the children, their work, and children are shown as they talk, play or are treated.

results.title: Smile for auntie
results.creator_credit: Morton Schindel, Weston Woods Studios and Gene Deitch
results.brief_description: A gently wicked satiric animated look at an aunt’s attempt to make baby smile. About the strange behaviour adults indulge in when attempting to communicate with, and relate to an infant. The aunt is seen from a child’s eye view. From the book written and illustrated by Diane Paterson. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Smart footwork
results.creator_credit: Toby Carpenter, Renown Pictures and Palfreeman Film Productions
results.brief_description: It is said that a man spends half of his life in his shoes, yet gives them less thought than any other article of apparel. Here in this film we watch the process of manufacture of footwear in a British factory, starting with the evil-smelling tannery where the hides are treated, and ending wiht someone’s feet in a smart pair of finished shoes. The film shows also examples of footwear worn as long ago as the 15th century, and watch master craftsmen at work on hand-made shoes.

results.title: Smallpox: merciless traveller
results.creator_credit: Czechoslovak Film Studios, World Health Organisation and Vaclav Bedrich
results.brief_description: This animated film deals with the history of smallpox throughout the ages. Shows how it has ravaged the world from the time of the Pharoahs, the discovery of a vaccine by Edward Jenner and his fight to have it recognised by international medical authorities and how the smallpox problem is being dealt with in the present day.

results.title: Small towns, big picture: a journey in building community
results.creator_credit: Judy Spokes, Philip Ashton, Maureen Rogers and Image Link
results.brief_description:
Five country towns in Central Victoria - Dunolly,
Wedderburn, Carisbrook, Maldon and Talbot - have been
involved in a social experimental project called “Small Towns Big Picture” for the last two years or more with the
Centre for Sustainable Regional Communities, La Trobe
University, Bendigo under the leadership of Dr Maureen
Rogers. Concern was being expressed about the demise of small country towns and their future, economically,
socially and environmentally and the main intention of the
Project was to develop a toolkit for measuring the “health” of a community - a benchmark for sustainability. With the assistance of Judy Spokes and the Cultural Development Network seven artists were commissioned to work with the communities and the researchers. Workshops were established incorporating the community, including the Energy Footprint Project and a Community Cohesion Project. Craig Christie (playwright) has been working on creating and producing a musical play in Carisbrook capturing the issues from the Community Cohesion focus group and auditioning the local
communities to perform in the play. This documentary
provides an inside view of the workings of “Small Towns Big Picture” and includes interviews with artists, project
leaders, councillors, teachers and members of the
community.
results.title_for_label: Small towns, big picture: a journey in building community
results.creator_credit_for_label: Judy Spokes, Philip Ashton, Maureen Rogers and Image Link
